reply_text: Hello sir/madam- I am sorry to hear that you felt I ordered unnecessary tests. Just to clarify and for your understanding there are very specific medications like valacicyclovir that are prescribed for chicken pox.  If untreated, chicken pox can possibly cause severe complications; so it would be very unwise to not treat chicken pox and assume it will heal on its own. When we initiate this medication in particular (valacicyclovir) we need to know if the patient‚Äôs renal profile is ok which is why a test like RFT (renal function test) is ordered otherwise the dose of valaciclovir definitely needs to be altered to protect the kidneys. If I do not know what the baseline renal function of the patient is when putting a patient on a medication that may impact the kidneys, I order the RFT for the purpose aforementioned. For patients who have coexisting other symptoms like Fever, throat pain etc we often order tests like CBC and maybe ESR or CRP to check the blood counts and levels of inflammation. Hope this clarifies the medical part of your disappointment. I would like to highlight that I practice medicine very ethically and keep my patient‚Äôs well being of utmost priority. Coming to the administrative part- if you consulted me at Kasper Clinic and if there was a registration charge you were asked to pay; that is something that the clinic may have charged you and I certainly don‚Äôt have any role in this nor do I specifically ask the clinic to collect this registration charge on my behalf; in case the clinic asked you to pay the registration charge again, I will ask them to issue you a refund.

reply_text:
Hello Madam: 

First and foremost, I would like to emphasize that for a physician, asking history about pregnancy, lactation and menstruation from female patients of reproductive age group is an essential requirement and global medical standard for clinical/medical history taking and patient evaluation. This is just as important as it is to know what the patient‚Äôs complaints are, the past medical/surgical history, which medications the patient is taking or is allergic to, family medical history etc.

It is extremely important for a physician to know during a consultation if a female patient of reproductive age group is pregnant or lactating (breast feeding) so that medications that are not supposed to be given during this time are withheld to not cause any harm to a growing fetus or breast fed child. In your case also this information was important to possibly withhold (if needed) certain antibiotics, pain medications, anti histamines or other medications for the same reasons as highlighted above.

Furthermore, irregularities in menstrual cycles may potentially point to other underlying patient medical conditions such as thyroid disorder/PCOD etc. based on which the physician may advise the patient to seek gynecologist opinion and/or provide appropriate treatment plans as deemed beneficial for the patient.

As a physician I consider my responsibility to not only treat the problem on hand but also to ensure that I cause no harm to the patient and help uncover and treat other medical problems that the patient may have.
